BE11:15am

Vodafone has released its 3Q18 trading statement with organic service revenue growth in line with consensus expectations of +1.1%. Within the mix Germany is better than expected by 0.4pp, Italy is broadly in line despite lapping price increases. Spain was 0.8pp below due to a promotional quarter and lower roaming in but we note price increases by all players recently should benefit calendar 2018. UK was 0.7pp below as fixed line projects dragged but underlying mobile improved from +1% to +1.6%. Excluding handset financing and regulation Vodafone grew group organic service revenues +2.3% (2Q18: +2.5%). Europe as a whole was in line at +0.3% vs consensus of +0.4%. India declined -14.2% excluding MTRs. Broadband net adds reaccelerated due to an uptick in Italy whilst Vodafone highlights that it added +496k NGN customers in Europe. European fixed service revenues increased +4.4% in the quarter. Guidance for the FY has been reiterated.

BE11:16am

And Citi.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Implications — We expect group growth to be similar next quarter as the easing of the MTR drag in Germany and easier comps in AMAP more or less offset UK handset financing. These figures reflect solid execution but are broadly in line

BE11:17am

The upshot here is that Vodacom numbers yesterday were positive and this isn't.

BE11:19am

Group service revenue growth inches lower, so we get a slowdown feel to the story rather than a growth one. Hence, 3% off the stock.

Clive Selley, Chief Executive of Openreach, said: "Through the Fibre First programme, Openreach is getting on with the job of building an Ultrafast Britain. We are accelerating our plans to build FTTP to three million premises by 2020 which sets the course to reach ten million by the mid-2020s with the right conditions. Where possible going forward, we will 'fibre first'.

Stateless BT 'sold'?! me fiber internet. Although when it came time to install it there was apparently no space in the exchange. #Organised. Currently getting free standard broadband from them till they eventually fix this. I'm sure that's good for their bottom line

Mouselet I suppose fibre switches are rather more voluminous than masses of very thin copper lines
11:23 am

And it's considered insensitive to the BT share price that, when the FT reported it last week, BT didn't feel it necessary to make any official comment?

Timmmmmmmyyyyyy Hi there, any news on IWG / Brookfield? Pusu deadline tomorrow...

3mn homes passed implies c10% of the UK
households, which is still far behind Spain and Portugal at more than 70%.
The statement adds that it will intend to cover 10mn premises with FTTP by mid-2020s as long as they generate an acceptable rate of return on the first 3 million premises. What is interesting in the statement is that Openreach claims that the build out costs have fallen: cost to pass per home of £300-400 vs £300-600 previously; cost to connect per home of £150-175 vs £175-200 previously.

rw42 @mouselet - no idea - maybe they're self-funding the cabinets by installing bitcoin miners in them :)

And Macquarie.

BE11:26am

[T]he announcement is a missed opportunity. The UK government wants 10m homes by the middle of the next decade. In our view BT could have signalled greater confidence in its outlook by announcing a long term objective. Indeed BT hopes to validate the FTTp business model over the next two years, but in reality we believe there will be limited educational benefits over this period which will be absorbed with building networks.

wayneJ There is a fibre that runs up the other side of our street (in a duct) to a local cabinet. We have a copper wire on a telegraph pole that swings when windy or cold. Trying to get fibre to the premises.......frankly I might end up moving house instead.
11:27 am

Anyway, since we're on broadband again, I should mention that RBC's knife catching TalkTalk this morning.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 122.30, up 3.3 (+2.77%), High: 124.40, Low: 118.80, Volume: 1.26m
Mouselet how many Kevlar gloves have people got out for Capita?
Shinshin I'm on an Exchange Only (EO) line. Can see the exchange from my house. Can't get fibre because EO isn't complicated enough for fibre to work...
DerivedCategory The other side of our road can now get 1Tbs internet for £21 a month. We cannot.
BE11:28am

Which was smashed nearly 20% this time yesterday by an Exane note very few people actually read.

wayneJ The other issue is the modelling that they do to decide where to put fibre - they tend to look at homes passed rather than the propensity to purchase and the life time value of the customer. Eg we have grass verges and ducts under them - so easy to roll out fibre vs digging up streets - but I don't think BT's spreadsheets can work that out.
hedgehog SIG?
11:28 am
BE11:28am

"Too much," says RBC.

BE11:28am

While TalkTalk is not without issues, we believe these concerns are overdone. TalkTalk's subs are growing and margin pressure should ease due to wholesale price reductions. Longer-term, BT's wholesale prices offer additional margin for Ultrafast products. Upgrading to Outperform, adding Speculative Risk qualifier, and lowering price target to 150p (from 190p).

BE11:28am

Key points:
Core business – revenue on the mend. TalkTalk’s subscriber inflection started in 4Q17 and is driven by the adoption off Fixed Low Price Plans (FLPP). Initially this dented revenues through lower ARPU but the effect is washing through due to the growing sub base. We expect TalkTalk to report top-line growth of +1.4% in FY2019 driven by +1.6% growth in On-Net revenue, with total revenue accelerating to +2.7% in FY2020.

Core business –margin pressure starting to lift. We explore the dynamics around margins. Having seen margins squeezed by fibre take up, Ofcom's proposed 40 Mbps fibre price (due to be implemtned by 1 April) should save up to £26m initially, rising to £50m by 2021. Furthermore Openreach's wholesale prices for Ultrafast products imply significant margin opporunity for TalkTalk.

Balance sheet and dividend. The balance sheet, whilst stretched, is not in danger, in our view. Peak leverage is at 3.1x in FY2018, comfortably below covenants at 4.0x. We also keep our dividend estimates intact, as the dividend carve-out on the covenants appears to offer sufficient headroom. As we discuss in our M&A section, a sale of the B2B business to a trade/financial buyer could be an interesting strategy. We estimate this could raise up to c.£500m and leave leverage at c.1.4x, leaving substantial capacity for an FTTH build programme.

M&A optionality. TalkTalk’s share price is down c.71% from its peak of c.400p in mid 2015. Given TalkTalk’s scale (c.4m Broadband subs, c.15.5% of the UK market), its large B2B telecoms unit, and its independent status, M&A is a possibility. We assess multiple options: (1) a take private; (2) reverse takeover by Daisy; (3) a sale of the B2B unit; and (iv) a takeover by a mobile operator.

Overall, we can see the rationale in refocusing R&D efforts given the delays to the pipeline (VR315 in particular) and one could argue it makes Vectura a more attractive asset to a potential suitor if it is a more focused player in the
generics space. However, whilst the R&D cuts should benefit EBITDA in the near term, the longer-term impact besides the lost assets is more difficult to assess today. We await further updates on the financials from the FY17 results, which are expected in March.

Regular readers will know that immediately after our early-January Strategy Conference, I de-camp to the Caribbean for two weeks in my personal fight against Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD – yes being bearish really does take a toll). This year we chose to visit Jamaica for the first time. Our colonial style hotel was previously the haunt of actors (Noel Coward), film stars (Marilyn Monroe), politicians (Winston Churchill), and royalty (Princess Margaret). Neither a State of Emergency being declared down the road in Montego Bay nor what locals said was the wettest January weather for decades prevented me absorbing large quantities of sunlight. I can reassure readers I am restored to my bearish best.

Although I agree with the bond bears that US yields will continue to rise, causing more problems for equities, I do not believe bond yields have yet seen a secular bottom. I repeat my forecast that US 10y yields will fall below zero.

BE11:42am

Here's Canaccord.

Pharma Another win for the auditors
BE11:43am

The overstatement relates to rebates and other
potential recoveries from suppliers in SIGD which have been brought to light following a whistle-blowing allegation of potential accounting irregularities. A review conducted with external auditors has found that profit for FY2016 was overstated by up to £3.7m, with up to £0.4m for years prior to 2016. Profits for H12017 were also overstated by up to £2.5m, with some additional receivables being accrued in H12017. The group intends
to restate these prior year financial statements and has engaged KPMG to conduct a detailed review of financial reporting controls at SIGD to confirm the accounting treatment of other material items at 31st December 2017, prior to finalizing the year-end results due on March 9th. A number of individuals have been suspended and are under a disciplinary investigation. Management confirmed that expectations for underlying profitability for FY2017 remain unchanged.

BE11:43am

While management has confirmed that expectations for FY2017 underlying profitability
remain unchanged, this will not help the credibility or confidence in the financials and is likely to have a negative impact on the rating of the shares, at least in the near term. Clearly, management is taking swift action to deal with these issues, but the recent announcements do highlight the fact the turnaround will not be a smooth journey. It also implies that the magnitude of the turnaround is greater than previously expected, given the implied lower starting point in terms of profits and higher net debt. Execution of the turnaround and reaching the recently stated targets remain the key issues for the investment case, but announcements like these highlight the challenges facing management. We await further clarification and reassurance around the financials at the upcoming results.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Shares reside on a 2018E PE of c.14 times and EV:Sales of c.0.42 times. Valuation focus should continue to be on where profitability and returns can get to in the medium term. On our forecasts, we would continue to expect the group to deliver EPS of c.18p by 2020 with a c.5% margin. Applying a 13 times PE or EV:Sales multiple of c.0.5 times implies a share price of c.230p or c.185p in current money; we take a slight discount for execution risk and arrive at our price target of 180p.

BE11:44am

And Davy ....

BE11:45am

It confirms that the underlying performance of the business over that period, which was isappointing in the first place, has actually been worse than originally believed. It also shines a further light on the operating challenges facing SIG. While frustrating, the actions now being taken and controls put in place by the new management team are necessary and are, therefore, to be welcomed. A further review of the specific business financial reporting controls has now been initiated with the help of KPMG. The uncovering of additional sub-standard practises can presumably not yet be ruled out.

While by 2019 the groups is not all the way thorough its recovery plan (we forecast a 4% EBIT margin, vs. its medium term target of 5%, we see ongoing risk to the group's end markets, competitive position and some execution risk, given that previous turnaround plans (albeit under previous management) have failed

PM11:49am

Late last week, our aggregate tactical indicator hit its
highest level of exuberance in the last 12 years. We choose not to interpret this as a clear sell signal for the following
reasons:

11:49 am
PM11:50am

Here's his reasoning

PM11:50am

Driven by sentiment indicators: The bulk of the move higher in our aggregate has come from survey-based sentiment
indicators. These have proved to be slightly unreliable as sell signals, with markets falling only 40% to 50% of the time in
the 1, 3 or 6 months following a comparable level being reached. Both the aggregate tactical and sentiment signals have
been much better buy than sell signals: euphoria lasts longer than panic!
 Equity Flows have not followed sentiment: extended bullish sentiment has, unusually, not reflected in meaningful equity
buying. There is a record gap between risk adjusted returns in equities versus bonds and flows into equities versus bonds
 Non-survey measures not extended: If we look at the non-survey based sentiment indicators (skew, put/call, inflows into
aggressive growth funds, speculative positioning and risk appetite), these indicators are only 0.6 standard deviations
extreme. In particular, risk appetite normally follows ISM new orders, and risk appetite is only 0.5 standard deviation above
its norm.
 Only 2 of the normal 13 preconditions of a market peak have been seen. The most reliable precursors for a sell-off (rising
credit spreads, over-investment, the probability of a recession being over 20%, a sharp acceleration in price momentum or
wage growth accelerating) have not been seen.
 Still fundamentally positive on equities: We still find: subdued wage growth, extremely strong earnings revisions, a high
equity risk premium (4.8% on our numbers, 5.8% on IBES - it should be 3.5% on our models), excess liquidity and funds
flow are all supportive for equities. Hence we agree with our US strategists' year-end target of 3,000 for the S&P 500. The
last time we had 17 months without a correction of 5% or more (December 1994 to May 1996), a correction of 7.5% ended
the run, but 6 and 12 months later equites were up 10.3% and 24.8%, respectively.
 What are the risks? We would highlight: i) labour getting pricing power (though we suspect the NAIRU is 3%-3.5%);
speculative grade default rate rises (they are, ex commodities, close to a 2 year high); the Fed start targeting asset prices
(this is unlikely); China slowing much more than expected or tech becoming clearly extended (it is not). The one risk areas
we are nervous of is cyclicals (ex tech and financials), which have priced themselves off extreme PMIs/ISMs.

BE11:56am

Refusing to engage on the first is just odd, as this is publically available data (mixture of expiring awards and frameworks). One could make the point that management’s guidance of 0% sales growth into 2019 requires many, if not all, to renew, but let’s leave that aside for the moment as we ignore this guidance, as we have been ignoring it for a couple of years. The second point is of greater interest. A couple of years ago, we drew investors’ attention to the apparent disinvestment post the 2008 GFC as proxied by the fall in capex below replacement rate. We thought that c.£0.25bn of free cash would be required to fix this, and suggested that his would drive FCF growth to zero (which today’s call effectively confirmed, FCF this year will be negative). Rather that guide on the level of underinvestment or on where margins were likely to trend, management were keen to distance themselves from Carillion (naturally!) and invite comparison with tech-rich and tech-enables businesses, so ….

…. for valuation purposes, let’s take them at their word and examine the cash and growth characteristics of Capgemini, Atos, Dassault, SAP, Indra, Sage, Amadeus, Sopra and Steria. We derive a trading level using this approach of 225p (assuming a rights issue at 180p) but this is a 4+ year turnaround in our view (while the CEO of CPI may not wish to make the comparison with Serco, the market will). What this means, is that the shares are unlikely to trade at that level for some time to come, but will instead trade on a depressed multiple of the c.21p of 2018 earnings that we forecast. On 8x, this puts our near term target price at 165p.

Barclays:

11:58 am
BE11:59am

Going forward there are still a number of issues that need to be addressed: 1) Scale and cost of the transformation (likely to be large, cost a lot and take time); 2) What value can be extracted from disposals? Capita’s average bolt-on purchase price has been in the region of 7-8x EBITA and as a forced seller it is not clear it will be able to command a premium for assets it decides to sell; 3) Is 1.0-1.5x net debt EBITDA low enough in an environment of contract inactivity, with significant contract rebids in 2019/20. Government scrutiny of public sector outsourcing is only going to increase, we believe, and that’s before the possibility of a Labour government (which we think would have negative implications for UK outsourcers)

BE11:59am

Bottom line, we believe Capita is a 5-year turnaround which is also up against profound change and uncertainty in many of its markets. This is a first and necessary step on the road recovery, but the lack of visibility coupled with experience at Serco (where three years in the recovery in revenue and profits is still elusive) will likely keep new money on the sidelines for a while yet.
